name: NPR
text: Federal government says patients in quarantine can now get their methadone delivered to them — if they follow security protocols. https://t.co/0aTo9Ll44u

name: NPR
text:
A new poll finds only 25% of black respondents plan to get a COVID-19 vaccine when one becomes available, compared to 56% of whites.
https://t.co/NNQyoNuGuq

name: NPR
text:
RT @TomDreisbach: When I first reported on this company, an employee called me a “dirty reporter.”

Their lawyer threatened a lawsuit, saying “Everyone wants to sue Dreisbach”.

Today, they were sued by the LA City Attorney for allegedly perpetrating multiple COVID scams.
 https://t.co/yZwvzqQcb3

name: NPR
text:
During the coronavirus pandemic, the Internet has become home to a growing number of self-published comics, and how-to guides for everything from cutting your hair to building emergency hand washing stations. 
https://t.co/X3XGccIPgA

name: NPR
text:
The city of Los Angeles is suing Wellness Matrix Group for allegedly selling "at-home" tests for the coronavirus, falsely claiming that the tests were FDA approved. 
https://t.co/cI2sYiOk3e

name: NPR
text:
The White House announced that seniors with diabetes will be able to sign up for Medicare plans that cap insulin costs at $35 per month, starting next year.
https://t.co/Ko9VBIMpCH

name: NPR
text:
Try and imagine your favorite artist today, playing a concert in someone's office in 2062 and still having an emotional impact with extraordinary new songs. 

That's essentially what Wire's Tiny Desk Concert will feel like to a lot of people. https://t.co/hPYd95EEZU

name: NPR
text:
During a boyhood in the Philippines, Meredith Talusan received positive reactions to the white skin and blonde hair accompanying albinism. 

She found a different response as a trans woman in the U.S.  https://t.co/LVkIs6sPbL

name: NPR
text:
Upon reopening, SeaWorld, Universal Orlando and Disney World all plan to limit attendance, perform temperature checks and require face coverings. 

Still, local health officials warn to prepare for a rise in COVID-19 cases. https://t.co/mm5vNXb8lO

name: NPR
text:
The proposed EU recovery fund — a mix of grants and loans — would be paid back over 30 years starting in 2028, in part with new taxes including a carbon tax, a digital tax and a tax on non-recycled plastics. 
https://t.co/Zjysmi5jaK

name: NPR
NPR
text: Marla Callistein’s son missed his chance to display his graphic design work before graduating college. So she made her front yard into a place to show off his art and connect with their neighbors. (@WBEZ) https://t.co/ipkbi0WJf5

name: NPR
text: “Ahmaud and I, we shared conversations about racism ... we both understood that our skin was considered a weapon – our blackness was considered a weapon.” @gpbnews hears about Arbery's life from friends and family. https://t.co/BBbLg3CSCe

name: NPR
text: Emily Domenech only planned to honor one person during her visit to Arlington National Cemetery, but by the time it closed Monday, she had fulfilled requests to visit dozens of other gravesites. @wamu885 https://t.co/M45DVh1Oh6

name: NPR
text:
In Dallas, Interstate 30 largely serves as a borderline between predominantly white neighborhoods to the north and predominantly black or Hispanic neighborhoods in the south.

There are 20 coronavirus testing sites in North Dallas.

Southern Dallas has 9. https://t.co/nmBg8gK5bw https://t.co/KKRBFjlS9r

name: NPR
text:
While researching his book "Breath," James Nestor participated in a study in which his nose was plugged for 10 days — forcing him to breathe solely through his mouth.

"My stress levels were off the charts. My nervous system was a mess. ... I felt awful." https://t.co/npYXpeET07

name: NPR
text:
A new survey shows the % of U.S. kids doing little or no remote learning: 

—from the lowest-income homes: 38%
—enrolled in special education: 35%
—from the wealthiest homes: 3.7% https://t.co/JUuS8QYTh8

name: NPR
text: NEW: Marc Short, the chief of staff to Vice President Pence, owns between $506,043 and $1.64 million worth of stocks in companies doing work linked to the Trump administration's pandemic response — including 3M, Abbott Labs and Gilead. https://t.co/zVMrffUASg

name: NPR
text:
More than one in four U.S. workers have lost their jobs since coronavirus shutdowns began.

Last week, an additional 2.1 million people filed for unemployment benefits. https://t.co/i3qN0EsjcS

name: NPR
text:
More than 60,000 health care workers have been infected from COVID-19, according to new data from the CDC. 

This data provides sobering evidence that many are still working in high-risk settings without adequate protection against the virus. https://t.co/daWAshaUqQ

name: NPR
text:
When the U.S. and Canada blocked nonessential travel across the border, it halted a way of life that residents fear may not return. 

"I don't think it'll be back to normal," one resident said, "It might take five or six years, I think." https://t.co/6Yd6cLaY0a

name: NPR
text: Prom portraits are a celebration of hard work, an era of life that has ended. The class of 2020 won't get that expe… https://t.co/JzzmO3G5k6

name: NPR
text:
Happening now: @jazznight is premiering a full live concert with Jon Batiste and Friends from a 2019 show in NYC — and @JonBatiste is hanging with fans in the comments. 

Tune in on YouTube: https://t.co/5gVmAPsiyT

name: NPR
text:
The Justice Department says the investigation into George Floyd's death is "a top priority" — and federal criminal charges are under consideration. 
https://t.co/SHZ9EK1suO

name: NPR
text:
Grab a pen, some paper and take 30 minutes to do something creative.

From Life Kit, here's how to make a #quaranzine. https://t.co/OYAbhL4vPU
